2020-08-14.abstract: The growing push to mine the seabed threatens the vast and rich ecosystem between the surface and the seafloor.
2020-08-14.snippet: The growing push to mine the seabed threatens the vast and rich ecosystem between the surface and the seafloor.
2020-08-14.lead_paragraph: There is treasure in the sea, and much of it lies in plain view on the deep ocean floor. Fields of metallic nodules and towering hydrothermal chimneys accumulate precious and industrially prized metals, estimated to be worth many billions to even trillions of dollars.
2020-08-14.headline_main: Treasure and Turmoil in the Deep Sea

2020-08-14.abstract: Helping young adults with the skills they need to transition to health care independence — with a bonus script for canceling appointments.
2020-08-14.snippet: Helping young adults with the skills they need to transition to health care independence — with a bonus script for canceling appointments.
2020-08-14.lead_paragraph: Owning your health care is a key life skill for young people, like doing laundry, voting and making ramen — and it’s one you can start learning, even (or especially) while living under your parents’ roof.
2020-08-14.headline_main: How Young People Can Own Their Health Care (Even if They Still See a Pediatrician)

2020-08-14.abstract: I had never told my father I loved him until he lay dying half a world away, body wrecked with coronavirus.
2020-08-14.snippet: I had never told my father I loved him until he lay dying half a world away, body wrecked with coronavirus.
2020-08-14.lead_paragraph: “Don’t thank me, love. It’s just my job.” The nurse’s words were clear, firm, efficient. Just like her, in the two hours I had known her.
2020-08-14.headline_main: The Particular Pain of Pandemic Grief

2020-08-14.abstract: She is the perfect person to build a case against the president.
2020-08-14.snippet: She is the perfect person to build a case against the president.
2020-08-14.lead_paragraph: Ladies and gentlemen of the jury, our case today is against the most powerful man in the world. And using the most powerful weapon of government by the people, you can hold this man accountable for the first time in his life, when you pass judgment on Nov. 3.
2020-08-14.headline_main: Kamala Harris, the Prosecutor Trump Fears Most

2020-08-14.abstract: Limited space, broken air-conditioning, windows that don’t work; nothing will be easy about reopening school this fall.
2020-08-14.snippet: Limited space, broken air-conditioning, windows that don’t work; nothing will be easy about reopening school this fall.
2020-08-14.lead_paragraph: Like all New York stories, the drama around the reopening of schools in the city is, in the end, a real estate story. It has the familiar whiplash plot — one that begins with hope and anticipation, is driven by obsession and uncertainty and then leaves you unraveled and scrambling for second- and third-rate solutions.
2020-08-14.headline_main: The Mayor Is Ready for School to Open. The School Buildings Are Not.

2020-08-14.abstract: As part of The Times’s Election 2020 event series, two journalists who have covered Kamala Harris and Joe Biden discussed the presumptive Democratic ticket.
2020-08-14.snippet: As part of The Times’s Election 2020 event series, two journalists who have covered Kamala Harris and Joe Biden discussed the presumptive Democratic ticket.
2020-08-14.lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
2020-08-14.headline_main: Two Campaign Reporters Put the Harris Pick in Perspective

2020-08-14.abstract: Belarusians took to the streets to reclaim their dignity. The government responded with brutal violence.
2020-08-14.snippet: Belarusians took to the streets to reclaim their dignity. The government responded with brutal violence.
2020-08-14.lead_paragraph: The opposition leader, fearing for her safety and her family, has been forced to flee. Peaceful protests have been met with violence: Hundreds wounded, two dead. People have disappeared into detention, violently pulled off the streets. And every night around 6 p.m., before the most brutal police violence begins, the internet is shut down. Belarus is under attack from its own government.
2020-08-14.headline_main: My Country Is Under Attack

2020-08-14.abstract: Drs. Ariel Schaap and Joshua Heisler, both internists who met as pre-med students 10 years ago, had a small outdoor wedding in Englewood, N.J. Then it was back to work.
2020-08-14.snippet: Drs. Ariel Schaap and Joshua Heisler, both internists who met as pre-med students 10 years ago, had a small outdoor wedding in Englewood, N.J. Then it was back to work.
2020-08-14.lead_paragraph: From the start, Ariel Schaap had cause to believe that Joshua Heisler might benefit from a caffeine infusion.
2020-08-14.headline_main: A Large Coffee and a Marriage Proposal to Go

2020-08-14.abstract: School leaders are running up against major obstacles and unanswerable questions ahead of the planned reopening. A large group of principals has called on the mayor to delay in-person instruction.
2020-08-14.snippet: School leaders are running up against major obstacles and unanswerable questions ahead of the planned reopening. A large group of principals has called on the mayor to delay in-person instruction.
2020-08-14.lead_paragraph: Alexa Sorden, an elementary school principal in the Bronx, has been pacing through the empty hallways of her school, trying to figure out how to make the most consequential school reopening effort in the country actually work.
2020-08-14.headline_main: N.Y.C. Schools Are Set to Open in a Month. Principals Fear That’s Too Soon.

2020-08-14.abstract: Stephen Ross, a billionaire developer, and Daniel Doctoroff, a tech executive, are trying to influence the 2021 mayoral race in New York.
2020-08-14.snippet: Stephen Ross, a billionaire developer, and Daniel Doctoroff, a tech executive, are trying to influence the 2021 mayoral race in New York.
2020-08-14.lead_paragraph: With less than a year before the Democratic mayoral primary, New York City’s business leaders are actively plotting how best to use their influence and money to shape the race to become Bill de Blasio’s successor.
2020-08-14.headline_main: Business Chiefs Seek N.Y.C. Mayoral Candidate, With $100 Million as Bait

2020-08-14.abstract: Mapping currents in the Southern Ocean is vital to monitoring climate change, but hard to conduct. So scientists turned to seals for help.
2020-08-14.snippet: Mapping currents in the Southern Ocean is vital to monitoring climate change, but hard to conduct. So scientists turned to seals for help.
2020-08-14.lead_paragraph: At the bottom of the planet is the Southern Ocean, its waters cold and roiling and sheathed with ice many months of the year.
2020-08-14.headline_main: How 14 Elephant Seals Assisted an Antarctic Ice Study

2020-08-14.abstract: For many suffragists, scholars have found, the freedom to choose whom and how they loved was tied deeply to the idea of voting rights.
2020-08-14.snippet: For many suffragists, scholars have found, the freedom to choose whom and how they loved was tied deeply to the idea of voting rights.
2020-08-14.lead_paragraph: In 1920, the suffragist Molly Dewson sat down to write a letter of congratulations to Maud Wood Park, who had just been chosen as the first president of the League of Women Voters, formed in anticipation of the passage of the 19th Amendment to help millions of women carry out their newfound right as voters.
2020-08-14.headline_main: How Queer Women Powered the Suffrage Movement

2020-08-14.abstract: Providing more aid to struggling governments has become one of the biggest issues tangling up the debate over another pandemic rescue package.
2020-08-14.snippet: Providing more aid to struggling governments has become one of the biggest issues tangling up the debate over another pandemic rescue package.
2020-08-14.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The U.S. economy struggled to shake off the last recession, with historically slow growth and a labor market that took more than six years to recover its earlier employment levels. A big part of the reason: state and local governments, which cut spending and fired workers amid widespread budget shortfalls.
2020-08-14.headline_main: State and Local Budget Pain Looms Over Economy’s Future

2020-08-14.abstract: Three current and former employees expressed concerns about the Chinese-owned app’s safeguards for preteen children.
2020-08-14.snippet: Three current and former employees expressed concerns about the Chinese-owned app’s safeguards for preteen children.
2020-08-14.lead_paragraph: If Microsoft or another company buys TikTok before President Trump bans the Chinese-owned video app on national security grounds, it will acquire a giant community of devoted fans and a lucrative platform for selling ads.
2020-08-14.headline_main: A Third of TikTok’s U.S. Users May Be 14 or Under, Raising Safety Questions

2020-08-14.abstract: Working and schooling from home for the foreseeable future has prompted some homeowners to consider major home renovations.
2020-08-14.snippet: Working and schooling from home for the foreseeable future has prompted some homeowners to consider major home renovations.
2020-08-14.lead_paragraph: Kristen Meehan’s home office is often a brown Adirondack chair on her front lawn, with hedges that make a halfway decent Zoom backdrop.
2020-08-14.headline_main: Renovating for a New Normal

2020-08-14.abstract: Struck hard by the pandemic, long-term and assisted living facilities shut their doors to outsiders. Many still have not reopened.
2020-08-14.snippet: Struck hard by the pandemic, long-term and assisted living facilities shut their doors to outsiders. Many still have not reopened.
2020-08-14.lead_paragraph: Three years ago, Cathy Baum helped both her mother and her mother-in-law move into memory care in an assisted living facility in Reston, Va. Because Ms. Baum lived nearby, she could visit four to five days a week and keep a watchful eye on them.
2020-08-14.headline_main: Nursing Home Families Yearn to Visit Loved Ones Again

2020-08-14.abstract: Should public school systems provide teachers for small-group instruction?
2020-08-14.snippet: Should public school systems provide teachers for small-group instruction?
2020-08-14.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Shy Rodriguez heard about one of the hottest trends in education during the pandemic — “learning pods,” where parents hire teachers for small-group, in-home instruction — she knew immediately it was something she could never afford for her sons.
2020-08-14.headline_main: Families Priced Out of ‘Learning Pods’ Seek Alternatives

2020-08-14.abstract: Sharing vacation adventures used to be fun. But during the pandemic, some travelers are content to let the tree fall in the forest, so to speak, without a single soul to hear it.
2020-08-14.snippet: Sharing vacation adventures used to be fun. But during the pandemic, some travelers are content to let the tree fall in the forest, so to speak, without a single soul to hear it.
2020-08-14.lead_paragraph: Next month, Elena Gaudino will fly from New York to Las Vegas, rent an S.U.V. and drive to the Grand Canyon, Joshua Tree National Park and other desert destinations. The 10-day road trip stands in for her favorite annual tradition — Burning Man, the Nevada arts festival that was canceled this year because of the pandemic — and gives her something to look forward to after a coronavirus-induced travel dry-spell.
2020-08-14.headline_main: Shhh! We’re Heading Off on Vacation

2020-08-14.abstract: 'Point a finger on a map, people are moving there.'
2020-08-14.snippet: 'Point a finger on a map, people are moving there.'
2020-08-14.headline_main: A Century-Old Moving Company Says the Summer of Covid Is ‘Insane’

2020-08-14.abstract: The radical fix for a noxious landfill in Staten Island: Bury the trash, plant some grass and do nothing for 20 years.
2020-08-14.snippet: The radical fix for a noxious landfill in Staten Island: Bury the trash, plant some grass and do nothing for 20 years.
2020-08-14.lead_paragraph: A little less than two decades ago, the last steaming load of garbage arrived at Fresh Kills Landfill. A packed-high barge turned slowly out of the Arthur Kill — that long, dishwater-brown tidal strait that separates Staten Island from New Jersey — and then docked at the Sanitation Department’s pier, an event celebrated less as a matter of ecological stewardship at the time than a triumph of not-in-my-backyard politics.
2020-08-14.headline_main: How the World’s Largest Garbage Dump Evolved Into a Green Oasis

2020-08-14.abstract: A new generation of activists is trying to figure out where to concentrate its efforts. Residential desegregation is the final frontier.
2020-08-14.snippet: A new generation of activists is trying to figure out where to concentrate its efforts. Residential desegregation is the final frontier.
2020-08-14.lead_paragraph: Last year in San Mateo, Calif., a history teacher at Hillsdale High School conducted a mock hearing of South Africa’s Truth and Reconciliation Commission. Sophia Heath, then a freshman, played an anti-apartheid lawyer. She recalls that she “was really excited and that was the beginning of where my activism started.” On the web, she found Coalition Z, a youth group that registers voters and presses officials to combat climate change, provide more equitable school funding and enact gun control. Ms. Heath started a local chapter.
2020-08-14.headline_main: The Black Lives Next Door

2020-08-14.abstract: Republican efforts to deny Senator Harris’s identity as an African-American and turn her into a noncitizen are destined to fail.
2020-08-14.snippet: Republican efforts to deny Senator Harris’s identity as an African-American and turn her into a noncitizen are destined to fail.
2020-08-14.lead_paragraph: It was probably inevitable that becoming Joe Biden’s running mate would result in controversy over Kamala Harris’s heritage.
2020-08-14.headline_main: Black Like Kamala

2020-08-14.abstract: Had she, in the throes of segregation and suffrage, cast a hard-won vote? I needed to know.
2020-08-14.snippet: Had she, in the throes of segregation and suffrage, cast a hard-won vote? I needed to know.
2020-08-14.lead_paragraph: I was looking for my grandmother. That meant spending a warm fall day in a reading room among reference books, microfilm reels and acid-free folders.
2020-08-14.headline_main: Tackling a Century-Old Mystery: Did My Grandmother Vote?

2020-08-14.abstract: Scholars and policymakers have proposed ways to fix the inequities between whites and people of color, including changes to Social Security and building wealth from birth.
2020-08-14.snippet: Scholars and policymakers have proposed ways to fix the inequities between whites and people of color, including changes to Social Security and building wealth from birth.
2020-08-14.lead_paragraph: The protest movement across the United States this summer has prompted a national conversation about ways to correct the acute economic inequities facing Black and other Americans of color. Those inequities don’t end when people retire.
2020-08-14.headline_main: America’s Retirement Race Gap, and Ideas for Closing It

2020-08-14.abstract: To understand the suffragists, and why their battle took so long, you also have to understand the anti-suffragists.
2020-08-14.snippet: To understand the suffragists, and why their battle took so long, you also have to understand the anti-suffragists.
2020-08-14.lead_paragraph: The sinking of the Titanic in 1912 inspired a flood of articles on seemingly every aspect of the disaster. One of the oddest appeared in The Woman’s Protest, a journal dedicated to opposing women’s suffrage.
2020-08-14.headline_main: The Women Who Fought Against the Vote

2020-08-14.abstract: A deck of cards cut from milk cartons. A wand made with medical tape. How a group of inmates learned “the magic of magic.”
2020-08-14.snippet: A deck of cards cut from milk cartons. A wand made with medical tape. How a group of inmates learned “the magic of magic.”
2020-08-14.lead_paragraph: When the magician Kris Nevling was released from prison two years ago, he had been incarcerated for most of his life.
2020-08-14.headline_main: In Prison, Learning Magic by Mail

2020-08-14.abstract: The couple reopened their 10-cabin lodge in the Catskills in May. They live close by, making music and gardening.
2020-08-14.snippet: The couple reopened their 10-cabin lodge in the Catskills in May. They live close by, making music and gardening.
2020-08-14.lead_paragraph: “I have been in Phase 1 since March,” said Kate Pierson, an original member of the inimitable new-wave band the B-52’s, who has run Kate’s Lazy Meadow, a rustic, funky getaway in Mount Tremper, New York, with her wife, Monica Coleman, an artist, since 2004. (They also have a sister property in Landers, Calif.)
2020-08-14.headline_main: How Kate Pierson, of the B-52’s, and Monica Coleman, Spend Their Sundays

2020-08-14.abstract: Cartoonists used the press to battle anti-suffrage stereotypes and create a new image for the movement to enfranchise women.
2020-08-14.snippet: Cartoonists used the press to battle anti-suffrage stereotypes and create a new image for the movement to enfranchise women.
2020-08-14.lead_paragraph: When Alice Paul recruited a cartoonist for her newspaper The Suffragist in 1914, the idea of that activist was already sketched in the public mind — and it was not pretty. Throughout the 19th century and into the 20th, Americans had encountered countless images showing women suffragists as old, mannish and unattractive. In pursuing the vote, women were portrayed as threatening national values, the sanctity of the home and their husbands’ masculinity.
2020-08-14.headline_main: Fighting for the Vote With Cartoons

2020-08-14.abstract: What the end of a long war might have been like for a sailor in Tokyo Bay on Sept. 2, 1945.
2020-08-14.snippet: What the end of a long war might have been like for a sailor in Tokyo Bay on Sept. 2, 1945.
2020-08-14.lead_paragraph: In remembrance of the day Japan first agreed to surrender, Aug. 15, the latest article from “Beyond the World War II We Know,” a series by The Times that documents lesser-known stories from the war, is a look back by James Stavridis, a retired United States Navy admiral and former supreme Allied Commander of NATO. He imagines how a sailor anchored in Tokyo Bay might have experienced the official surrender ceremony on Sept. 2.
2020-08-14.headline_main: The Japanese Surrender: A Sailor’s Perspective

2020-08-14.abstract: An artist with schizoaffective disorder shares her strategy for self-care.
2020-08-14.snippet: An artist with schizoaffective disorder shares her strategy for self-care.
2020-08-14.headline_main: Welcome to the Covid-19 Mental Health Struggle

2020-08-14.abstract: People who recover from the virus have a three-month window of safety, C.D.C. guidance shows. The U.S. Postal Service warned several states that it may not be able to meet deadlines for delivering last-minute mail-in ballots.

2020-08-14.abstract: Ron Bel Bruno and Edward Goldberg, a 50-something couple, connected quickly after meeting online. “It was instant. It was instant. It was instant.”
2020-08-14.snippet: Ron Bel Bruno and Edward Goldberg, a 50-something couple, connected quickly after meeting online. “It was instant. It was instant. It was instant.”
2020-08-14.lead_paragraph: Ron Bel Bruno had at least 27 years of experience with internet dating, he said, when he encountered Dr. Edward Goldberg online in September 2016.

2020-08-14.abstract: A cherry-sorting warehouse in Washington State was where they met, but when they decided to be together, it was outside of the other Washington.
2020-08-14.snippet: A cherry-sorting warehouse in Washington State was where they met, but when they decided to be together, it was outside of the other Washington.
2020-08-14.lead_paragraph: A windowless, fluorescent-lit warehouse, in Wenatchee, Wash., where millions upon millions of cherries — Bings, Sweethearts, Raniers, Tietons — are sorted and graded and packaged each summer, was where the romance between Corena Sharp and Mark Olson began.
2020-08-14.headline_main: Those Night-Shift Talks Were Easy as Pie

2020-08-14.abstract: Rabbi Jennifer Gubitz got Matan BenYishay’s three-month-old message on the dating app JDate after renewing her lapsed membership.
2020-08-14.snippet: Rabbi Jennifer Gubitz got Matan BenYishay’s three-month-old message on the dating app JDate after renewing her lapsed membership.
2020-08-14.lead_paragraph: After Rabbi Jennifer Anne Gubitz reactivated her lapsed dating app memberships and joined new ones in August 2017, she was intrigued by a three-month-old message on JDate from Matan BenYishay who had the screen name TzedekNerd (tzedek means justice in Hebrew).
2020-08-14.headline_main: Three Months Later, She Replied

2020-08-14.abstract: They met after college, but their relationship didn’t develop until years later in Washington, after she saw him jogging by the car she was in.
2020-08-14.snippet: They met after college, but their relationship didn’t develop until years later in Washington, after she saw him jogging by the car she was in.
2020-08-14.lead_paragraph: Shortly after graduating from college in 2003, Marisol Orihuela and Mark Roland both ended up living in the same Atlanta house that was sponsored by the Jesuit Volunteer Corps, to which both had enlisted for a year of public service.
2020-08-14.headline_main: He Jogged Back Into Her Life

2020-08-14.abstract: Ron Carlivati, the head writer for a daytime drama, says David Rogal, who he met at a movie theater, prevents his life from becoming a soap opera.
2020-08-14.snippet: Ron Carlivati, the head writer for a daytime drama, says David Rogal, who he met at a movie theater, prevents his life from becoming a soap opera.
2020-08-14.lead_paragraph: While Ron Carlivati has made a career out of writing soap operas, his longtime partner, David Rogal, often prevents Mr. Carlivati’s life from becoming one.
2020-08-14.headline_main: New Role for a Soap Opera Writer: Husband

2020-08-14.abstract: As Kara Maser began slicing a birthday cake her sister made novelty diamond rings tumbled out, and Barry Funt got down on one knee with the real one.
2020-08-14.snippet: As Kara Maser began slicing a birthday cake her sister made novelty diamond rings tumbled out, and Barry Funt got down on one knee with the real one.
2020-08-14.lead_paragraph: When Kara Weiss Maser got Barry Marc Funt’s text in March 2019 out of the blue, she figured it had to do with some community-related activity. Two decades earlier he had lived across the street from her in Livingston, N.J., when they were both married with small children.
2020-08-14.headline_main: It Might Have Been Called a Carat Cake

2020-08-14.abstract: The couple met at Yale, in an unconventional marching band, and by the time they got to Kansas, years later, they knew they belonged together.
2020-08-14.snippet: The couple met at Yale, in an unconventional marching band, and by the time they got to Kansas, years later, they knew they belonged together.
2020-08-14.lead_paragraph: The first time Henry Chapman asked out Melinda Becker, an acquaintance at Yale, where both were members of the imprecise and non-marching Yale Precision Marching Band, she was not entirely convinced he was being up front with her.
2020-08-14.headline_main: Perfectly in Sync During a 35-State Road Trip and a 1,200-Mile Hike

2020-08-14.abstract: The many roads traveled by Shana Caro and Georgina Emerson eventually led to each other, via the dating app Hinge, in February 2018.
2020-08-14.snippet: The many roads traveled by Shana Caro and Georgina Emerson eventually led to each other, via the dating app Hinge, in February 2018.
2020-08-14.lead_paragraph: Shana Caro, a 31-year-old scientist at Columbia University who grew up in White Plains, N.Y., has lived in Borneo, Costa Rica, Uganda, Kenya, Oxford, and a tiny town in the Netherlands called Wageningen.
2020-08-14.headline_main: Two World Travelers Find Love Close to Home

2020-08-14.abstract: A writer who moved upstate for a slower lifestyle fears that the latest wave of migrants, fleeing Covid, will bring their worst instincts with them.
2020-08-14.snippet: A writer who moved upstate for a slower lifestyle fears that the latest wave of migrants, fleeing Covid, will bring their worst instincts with them.
2020-08-14.lead_paragraph: Kingston, a small city in upstate New York, became my home four and a half years ago. Seeking space, affordability, green, and quiet, my husband and I traded Brooklyn for this city of 23,000. Unwittingly, we joined a slow-drip migration north.
2020-08-14.headline_main: Kingston: A City Remade by the Coronavirus

2020-08-14.abstract: How an assistant apparel designer at Adidas came to lead daily protests against her employer’s handling of race.
2020-08-14.snippet: How an assistant apparel designer at Adidas came to lead daily protests against her employer’s handling of race.
2020-08-14.lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher
2020-08-14.headline_main: Protesting Her Own Employer

2020-08-14.abstract: Alex Song and Kelly Jean Qu met three years ago just as she was preparing to leave New York. But then she decided to stay.
2020-08-14.snippet: Alex Song and Kelly Jean Qu met three years ago just as she was preparing to leave New York. But then she decided to stay.
2020-08-14.lead_paragraph: By the time Alex Song said his first hello to Kelly Jean Qu in September 2017, she was saying goodbye to New York, where she had lived for nearly three years, and on the verge of moving back to her native Los Angeles.
2020-08-14.headline_main: Attracted by Their ‘Intellectual Curiosity’

2020-08-14.abstract: Drs. Chloe Ciccariello and Krishn Khanna, who met at Columbia, got off to a shaky start, but eventually hit it off in chemistry class.
2020-08-14.snippet: Drs. Chloe Ciccariello and Krishn Khanna, who met at Columbia, got off to a shaky start, but eventually hit it off in chemistry class.
2020-08-14.lead_paragraph: Dr. Chloe Ciccariello remembers looking forward to a quiet nap one day in August 2006 at her Columbia dormitory, which was then assigned mostly to freshman engineering students. Suddenly the deafening sounds of electric guitar music outside her door roused her from bed in search of the source.
2020-08-14.headline_main: He Got Her Attention, but the Guitar Hero Had to Go

2020-08-14.abstract: We’re terrified of censure, too. Are there better ways to raise our children amid a pandemic?
2020-08-14.snippet: We’re terrified of censure, too. Are there better ways to raise our children amid a pandemic?
2020-08-14.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — My friend had been quarantining with her family in a suburb of San Antonio for several months when she began to worry that her three young children were becoming clinically depressed.
2020-08-14.headline_main: Parents Are Frightened, and Not Just About Contagion

2020-08-14.abstract: And what else you need to know today.
2020-08-14.snippet: And what else you need to know today.
2020-08-14.lead_paragraph: A postmaster general who’s a major Trump donor. A sweeping Postal Service reorganization. And a president who said on Thursday that he opposed emergency funding to support voting by mail.
2020-08-14.headline_main: Trump vs. the Post Office

2020-08-14.abstract: Lt. Col. Iman Elman, who was born in Somalia but raised in Canada in a family of peace activists, sees herself as continuing that tradition from a different platform.
2020-08-14.snippet: Lt. Col. Iman Elman, who was born in Somalia but raised in Canada in a family of peace activists, sees herself as continuing that tradition from a different platform.
2020-08-14.lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — When Iman Elman decided to enlist in the Somali National Army in 2011, the officer distributing uniforms gave her one shirt and two pairs of pants. Puzzled, Ms. Elman asked about the missing shirt. There was none, he said. The extra set of pants was provided for her to sew into a skirt.
2020-08-14.headline_main: Somalia’s Army Told Her to Sew a Skirt. Now She’s One of Its Top Officers.

2020-08-14.abstract: As a prosecutor she can make you tremble. But as a trailblazer can she make you cry?
2020-08-14.snippet: As a prosecutor she can make you tremble. But as a trailblazer can she make you cry?
2020-08-14.lead_paragraph: When I saw on Wednesday morning that Kamala Harris had released a short video marking and celebrating her selection as Joe Biden’s running mate, I clicked — eagerly and instantly. I wanted to continue riding my wave of excitement about all the firsts: first woman of color on a major party’s presidential ticket, first Black woman specifically, first Asian-American.
2020-08-14.headline_main: The Undertold, Undersold Story of Kamala Harris

2020-08-14.abstract: And Trump revives a racist conspiracy theory: This is your morning tip sheet.
2020-08-14.snippet: And Trump revives a racist conspiracy theory: This is your morning tip sheet.
2020-08-14.lead_paragraph: Joe Biden called for mask mandates, and President Trump wavered on funding for the post office. It’s Friday, and this is your politics tip sheet. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.

2020-08-14.abstract: Play can feel silly, unproductive and time consuming. And that’s precisely the point.
2020-08-14.snippet: Play can feel silly, unproductive and time consuming. And that’s precisely the point.
2020-08-14.lead_paragraph: “Let’s play!” my friend’s 4-year-old squealed, tugging on my arm. I was tired, so I told her, “I’m too lazy to play.” But I wasn’t allowed to be lazy because I’m big, she said. Unable to come up with a convincing rebuttal, I found a place to hide while she counted to 20. Fred Rogers said that play is “the work of childhood.” Kids take this work seriously, they’re good at it, and they can teach us a thing or two about why play is important — especially now.
2020-08-14.headline_main: How to Add More Play to Your Grown-Up Life, Even Now

2020-08-14.abstract: What did our critics think of the histories, memoirs and novels that explored the road to the 19th Amendment?
2020-08-14.snippet: What did our critics think of the histories, memoirs and novels that explored the road to the 19th Amendment?
2020-08-14.lead_paragraph: On Aug. 18, 1920, the 19th amendment was ratified, marking a pivotal moment in the fight for women's rights. This centennial has provided myriad opportunities to reflect on the amendment’s legacy — from the newfound parity the vote represented to the sidelining and enduring disenfranchisement faced by women of color. Even before the amendment’s passage, debates about the women’s movement were taking place in the pages of the Book Review. Women’s history and early feminist thought were newly available to readers as writers attempted to understand the “new woman” and her goals. In these archival pieces, reviewers consider the merits of suffrage literature — and occasionally, of suffrage itself.
2020-08-14.headline_main: How the Battle for Women’s Suffrage Played Out in the Pages of the Book Review

2020-08-14.lead_paragraph: There are some summer evenings so steamy that the only thing I can bear to eat is a giant bowl of leafy salad. And this whole month of August has been full of those kinds of nights, one sticky sunset after the next.

2020-08-14.lead_paragraph: Hi! And welcome to Five Weeknight Dishes. What day is it again? Oh, right. It’s Friday. Happy Friday! (Does T.G.I.F. mean anything to anyone anymore?) 2020-08-14.lead_paragraph: Museums and other cultural institutions will be allowed to open in New York City starting on Aug. 24, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said on Friday, following five months of a pandemic shutdown that has resulted in substantial layoffs and financial crises for many of these organizations.
2020-08-14.headline_main: Museums and Other New York Cultural Institutions Can Open Aug. 24

2020-08-14.abstract: Black activists in Chicago. Retail in Manhattan. An elephant’s pandemic journey. Bike shorts. And more.
2020-08-14.snippet: Black activists in Chicago. Retail in Manhattan. An elephant’s pandemic journey. Bike shorts. And more.
2020-08-14.lead_paragraph: Welcome to the weekend. This week, we had major news in the U.S. presidential race: Joe Biden’s selection of Sen. Kamala Harris as his running mate. As we get closer to the fall, the election season is intensifying, and it will continue to do so over the next two weeks with the Democratic and Republican conventions. So before all of that starts, try to take a break from the news cycle. Maybe make some homemade ice cream. Or enjoy a bit of moth-watching. But still make time for some incredible journalism.
2020-08-14.headline_main: 11 of Our Best Weekend Reads

2020-08-14.abstract: New Dance Alliance announces a residency program and its first three recipients: Angie Pittman, Johnnie Cruise Mercer and Leslie Cuyjet.
2020-08-14.snippet: New Dance Alliance announces a residency program and its first three recipients: Angie Pittman, Johnnie Cruise Mercer and Leslie Cuyjet.
2020-08-14.lead_paragraph: When the staff, leadership and advisory committee of the New Dance Alliance gathered to draft a letter in support of the Black Lives Matter movement, the group soon realized that words wouldn’t be enough to demonstrate the organization’s commitment to racial justice. “It became really apparent to us that, unless we were backing it up programmatically, whatever we were writing was hollow,” Fernando Maneca, the president of the Dance Alliance’s board, said in an interview.
2020-08-14.headline_main: A Space for Black Dance Artists to Create in the Hudson Valley

2020-08-14.abstract: It could be argued that he, even more than Andrés Segovia, established the guitar’s credibility as a serious solo instrument.
2020-08-14.snippet: It could be argued that he, even more than Andrés Segovia, established the guitar’s credibility as a serious solo instrument.
2020-08-14.lead_paragraph: Julian Bream, the English musician who pushed the guitar beyond its Spanish roots and expanded its range by commissioning dozens of works from major composers, and who also played a crucial role in reviving the lute as a modern concert instrument, died on Friday at his home in Wiltshire, England. He was 87.
2020-08-14.headline_main: Julian Bream, Maestro of Guitar and Lute, Dies at 87

2020-08-14.abstract: Obesity is not an independent risk for women, according to a new study, perhaps because their fat is distributed differently.
2020-08-14.snippet: Obesity is not an independent risk for women, according to a new study, perhaps because their fat is distributed differently.
2020-08-14.lead_paragraph: The coronavirus has been an unpredictable foe from the start. It triggers silent or barely perceptible infections in some individuals, while in others it sets off a cascade of complications that overwhelm the body and lead to death.

2020-08-14.lead_paragraph: You could hear that the new Apple TV+ sitcom “Ted Lasso” is based on a pair of one-joke video promos, made for NBC Sports, and have a “What is the world coming to?” moment. But that would just mean you had forgotten about “Cavemen” (2007), based on a series of Geico ads, or “Hey Vern, It’s Ernest” (1988), an outgrowth of local spots featuring the supremely annoying Ernest P. Worrell.
2020-08-14.headline_main: ‘Ted Lasso’ Review: Jason Sudeikis as America’s Nicest Export

2020-08-14.abstract: Plus: Mending a deflated marriage.
2020-08-14.snippet: Plus: Mending a deflated marriage.
2020-08-14.lead_paragraph: We’ve all had moments in our lives when we’ve felt like there was absolutely nothing that could turn our luck around. For Naomie Brinvilus, a writer from Haiti, that moment came after her country’s devastating 2010 earthquake, which left her family homeless and hungry. Feeling desperate, she sought help from a spiritual guide. His prescription of a wooden spoon, green onion, a young rooster and other talismans would not only bring her into a promised season of good fortune, it would also lead her to find love with a handsome stranger in the most unlikely of places — a cholera treatment center.
2020-08-14.headline_main: Love Letter: A Prescription for Despair

2020-08-14.abstract: Marilyn Stasio finds much to like in the latest batch of crime novels, filled with abrasive, unpleasant sorts.
2020-08-14.snippet: Marilyn Stasio finds much to like in the latest batch of crime novels, filled with abrasive, unpleasant sorts.
2020-08-14.lead_paragraph: Plucky heroines make me queasy. (It takes so much energy to be plucky.) The protagonist of Katie Tallo’s first novel, DARK AUGUST (HarperCollins, 448 pp., paper; $16.99), is better than that. Augusta (Gus) Monet is smart and resourceful, just too stubborn to know when to quit. When she returns to her hometown — Elgin, Ontario, “a town that once was but is no more” — her instinct is to burn it down. But “greed and spite and toxic wastewater” from fracking have taken care of that already. So her only business here is to claim the house (and the old dog who comes with it) left to her by her great-grandmother.
2020-08-14.headline_main: Plucky Characters? Ugh. Make Mine Prickly and Difficult.

2020-08-14.lead_paragraph: The stories of gender exclusion I heard this week from women working at Pinterest and their former colleagues were numbingly similar, with most using the same words over and over again: Sidelined. Shut down. Doors closed. Inner circles. Toxic secrecy. Homegrown boys club. Left out of meetings. Out of key decisions. Out of promotions. Out.

2020-08-14.lead_paragraph: Are Zoom happy hours still the way to “go out,” five months after Covid-19 locked much of the country indoors? Most nondrinkers probably wouldn’t be able to say. It gets tiresome watching friends slowly sip on whiskey after their Collins glasses of sparkling water have gone empty. Eventually, nondrinkers bow out.
2020-08-14.headline_main: Pleasantly Bitter and Thoroughly Grown-Up, No Alcohol Needed

2020-08-14.abstract: Amid the real-life terrors of a pandemic, the writer takes solace in this long-running British crime series, which may be the only TV drama whose title character is a corpse.
2020-08-14.snippet: Amid the real-life terrors of a pandemic, the writer takes solace in this long-running British crime series, which may be the only TV drama whose title character is a corpse.
2020-08-14.lead_paragraph: It may sound perverse, if not masochistic, to say that I’ve spent weeks of quarantine watching autopsies. But these procedures have been the ultimate escape: Taking place in a distant, fictional environment, they usually involve an agent of death that isn’t a volatile, out-of-control virus but a volatile, out-of-control human being. (At least a relentless person’s range is limited.)
2020-08-14.headline_main: Comfort Viewing: 3 Reasons I Love ‘Silent Witness’

2020-08-14.abstract: For years, the young outfielder has been too flawed to play full-time but too talented to trade away. Now, a series of Yankees injuries has given him a fresh chance to make his mark.

2020-08-14.abstract: Start with steak Diane for two.
2020-08-14.snippet: Start with steak Diane for two.
2020-08-14.lead_paragraph: Welcome. The weekend is upon us again, though for many it’ll be no different from the other days that we pass by like towns off the interstate, long-haul truckers driving endlessly through the night. It’s hard to distinguish between them when we spend so much time in the same space at home, working or not working, screening or not screening, marking or not marking the time. Everything looks like blacktop.

But you won’t find cast and crew members in Los Angeles County, where coronavirus cases remain high and testing is scarce. Instead, studios are shooting overseas, bringing numerous safety protocols with them. Among the first test cases is Universal’s “Jurassic World: Dominion,” which has become a model for moviemaking in the Covid-19 era.

2020-08-14.snippet: A thrashing in the Champions League quarterfinals showed Bayern Munich at the peak of its powers and Barcelona at the end of the line.
2020-08-14.lead_paragraph: Lionel Messi turned his back. He had given the ball away, but he made no effort to atone for his error, no attempt to regain control. He stopped, waited a beat, and then looked to the other end of the field. It was as if he knew what was going to happen, and he did not care — or could not bear — to watch.
2020-08-14.headline_main: Bayern 8, Barcelona 2. The End.

2020-08-14.abstract: Italy coheres as America breaks apart.
2020-08-14.snippet: Italy coheres as America breaks apart.
2020-08-14.lead_paragraph: SANTA MARGHERITA, Italy — In Italy there are seasons — and then there is the season. Summer comes, the country’s woes are set aside, and, to the eternal refrain of “tutti al mare” (“Everyone to the sea”), the exodus to the consoling coast begins. The national debt fades between sea and stars.
2020-08-14.headline_main: The Unlikely Triumph of Italian Nationhood

2020-08-15.abstract: Catch this engaging political documentary, and a series about dating in pre-pandemic New York City.
2020-08-15.snippet: Catch this engaging political documentary, and a series about dating in pre-pandemic New York City.
2020-08-15.lead_paragraph: BOYS STATE (2020) Stream on Apple TV+. Every year, hundreds of high-school-aged boys in Texas head to Austin for a weeklong mock government exercise known as Boys State. In 2018, the married filmmakers Jesse Moss and Amanda McBaine embedded in the fray, following four of the participants as their parties drafted platforms and elected key officials, including a governor. In the process, the filmmakers capture a hopeful demonstration of democracy that also reflects the hyper-polarized tensions of politics today. In her New York Times review, Manohla Dargis wrote that “the filmmakers have made an engaging movie about some kids who — as their jokes give way to debates, stratagems and even shocks — already seem to be drafting their own more interesting sequel.”
2020-08-15.headline_main: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘Boys State’ and ‘Platonic’

2020-08-15.abstract: N.H.L. teams’ raucous home arena traditions have persisted, with tweaks, in the postseason hub cities.
2020-08-15.snippet: N.H.L. teams’ raucous home arena traditions have persisted, with tweaks, in the postseason hub cities.
2020-08-15.lead_paragraph: EDMONTON — In any other year, they would be waging battle in the Fortress, the nickname for T-Mobile Arena, where the Vegas Golden Knights notoriously defend home ice to the tune of a 75-33-11 record over three seasons, fifth-best in the N.H.L.
2020-08-15.headline_main: Recreating Home Ice, Far From Home

2020-08-15.abstract: The acclaimed novelist and story writer, who died in 2003, depicted the everyday experiences and domestic concerns of women — themes that deserve more literary recognition.
2020-08-15.snippet: The acclaimed novelist and story writer, who died in 2003, depicted the everyday experiences and domestic concerns of women — themes that deserve more literary recognition.
2020-08-15.lead_paragraph: When Carol Shields died of breast cancer in 2003, her obituary in The New York Times remembered her as a novelist whose work highlighted the “profundity of the mundane,” while The Guardian mentioned her “commitment to commemorating otherwise ordinary lives.” Shields specialized in fiction devoted to women characters and their experience; nearly two decades later, the province of “ordinary” women in fiction still needs defending. Earlier this year, a generously endowed new literary prize for women writers was announced in Shields’s name — a choice made in part, one of the award’s founders explained, to underscore the value of domestic concerns in literature, which too often have been considered unworthy of serious fiction.
2020-08-15.headline_main: The Radical Ordinariness of Carol Shields’s Literary World

2020-08-15.abstract: Lessing’s 1962 novel is far from a manifesto. But in its embrace of chaos and split identities, it captures the mood of both its time and ours.
2020-08-15.snippet: Lessing’s 1962 novel is far from a manifesto. But in its embrace of chaos and split identities, it captures the mood of both its time and ours.
2020-08-15.lead_paragraph: When Doris Lessing, the British-Zimbabwean novelist who died in 2013, sat down to write “The Golden Notebook” in the 1950s, she was responding to a feeling of defeat in leftist circles, one similar to the whiplash experienced by liberals after the election of President Trump. The marquee intellectual philosophy of the young 20th century — communism — was sagging from the revelation that “Father Stalin” had overseen the death of millions; communist stalwarts in the West, like Lessing, felt they’d had the carpet pulled out from under them. They became intellectually homeless. Meanwhile, Senator Joseph McCarthy was raving like a proto-Trump at left-leaning Americans. What had this generation’s progressive causes amounted to?
2020-08-15.headline_main: Doris Lessing’s ‘Golden Notebook’ and Our Era of Unrest

2020-08-15.abstract: There were surprises this week that weren’t entirely shocking: Ms. Harris joined Joe Biden’s ticket and President Trump resurrected birtherism. Here’s what to make of the last week in politics.

2020-08-15.lead_paragraph: For months, public health experts and federal officials have said that significantly expanding the number of coronavirus tests administered in the United States is essential to reining in the pandemic. By some estimates, several million people might need to be tested each day, including many people who don’t feel sick.
2020-08-15.headline_main: ‘We’re Clearly Not Doing Enough’: Drop in Testing Hampers Coronavirus Response

2020-08-15.abstract: Researchers have used reflective prisms left on the moon’s surface for decades, but had increasingly seen problems with their effectiveness.
2020-08-15.snippet: Researchers have used reflective prisms left on the moon’s surface for decades, but had increasingly seen problems with their effectiveness.
2020-08-15.lead_paragraph: The moon is drifting away. Every year, it gets about an inch and a half farther from us. Hundreds of millions of years from now, our companion in the sky will be distant enough that there will be no more total solar eclipses.

2020-08-15.abstract: For many students this fall, “college” will be their childhood bedroom or family dining room. Here’s how parents can help make the experience easier for everyone.
2020-08-15.snippet: For many students this fall, “college” will be their childhood bedroom or family dining room. Here’s how parents can help make the experience easier for everyone.
2020-08-15.lead_paragraph: Every day, it seems, another college abandons in-person plans in favor of starting the fall semester online. Along with the crushing disappointment, first-year students now have to navigate the transition to college without the accompanying freedom of leaving home. And parents may face behaviors and habits — sleeping until noon, skipping class — they wouldn’t see if the student were away at school.

2020-08-15.abstract: Some buildings are playing hardball when it comes to enforcing pandemic rules. But how much power do they really have?

2020-08-15.lead_paragraph: Q: I live in a co-op in Riverdale. Building management has sent out several notices requesting that residents wear masks at all times when in the common areas of the buildings. But the co-op took it a step further, writing an email threatening to assess fines to any resident who fails to comply with the requirements. Does the co-op have the authority to assess fines for failure to wear masks?
2020-08-15.headline_main: Can Co-ops Fine Residents for Not Wearing Masks?

2020-08-15.abstract: The pandemic has many people thinking about how they’ll spend time outside as the weather cools, meaning favorite items may soon be in short supply.
2020-08-15.snippet: The pandemic has many people thinking about how they’ll spend time outside as the weather cools, meaning favorite items may soon be in short supply.
2020-08-15.lead_paragraph: Toilet paper notwithstanding, the best thing Todd Osterman did back in April was start thinking about how to furnish his patio. But really, “my wife was the one who was thinking way ahead,” the Wisconsin teacher said. “She was the one who thought this might be a long-term thing.” If they were going to be home all summer, they might as well enjoy their patio — which meant getting a heater for those early-spring nights.
2020-08-15.headline_main: Don’t Wait to Deck Out Your Back Porch

2020-08-15.lead_paragraph: Garage bands, first kisses, broken friendships; it’s a winning combination. ALL TOGETHER NOW (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, 192 pp., $12.99; ages 10 to 14), from the acclaimed comics creator Hope Larson, tackles all these topics and more in a story that feels fresh, and will be immediately relatable to a middle grade audience.

2020-08-15.abstract: A supporter of the dangerous conspiracy theory won a primary runoff on Tuesday. The social media platforms have some soul-searching to do.
2020-08-15.snippet: A supporter of the dangerous conspiracy theory won a primary runoff on Tuesday. The social media platforms have some soul-searching to do.
2020-08-15.lead_paragraph: For almost three years, I’ve wondered when the QAnon tipping point would arrive — the time when a critical mass of Americans would come to regard the sprawling pro-Trump conspiracy theory not merely as a sideshow, but as a legitimate threat to safety and even democracy.
2020-08-15.headline_main: QAnon Was a Theory on a Message Board. Now It’s Headed to Congress.

2020-08-15.abstract: The sash has had an improbable journey, worn by both suffragists and bachelorettes.
2020-08-15.snippet: The sash has had an improbable journey, worn by both suffragists and bachelorettes.
2020-08-15.lead_paragraph: A sash — a piece of fabric draped over the head and worn from the shoulder to the opposite hip — is a strange garment. Its purpose is, essentially, decorative, but it has been worn for decoration by many types: It was part of male military dress uniforms in Europe at least as long ago as the 16th century. Royalty make use of them as well — you may recall that at his 2011 wedding, Prince William wore a bright blue sash with his dress uniform, and Princess Grace of Monaco frequently appeared in hers, an Order of St. Charles band.
2020-08-15.headline_main: The Single Strip of Fabric That Went From ‘Votes for Women’ to ‘Miss America’

2020-08-15.abstract: For some, the senator’s being on the Democratic ticket is about more than just the vice presidency.
2020-08-15.snippet: For some, the senator’s being on the Democratic ticket is about more than just the vice presidency.
2020-08-15.lead_paragraph: Joe Biden’s selection of Senator Kamala Harris to be his running mate is historic. She is the first Black woman and the first person of Indian descent to be on a major-party ticket and, should Biden win, stands that much closer to becoming the first female president in our nation’s history. It’s no surprise that many Americans are emotional about her being chosen.
2020-08-15.headline_main: ‘Kamala Harris’s Nomination Is Everything to Me’

2020-08-15.abstract: He’s not out on the campaign trail now, but when he was a young man in a hurry, he told us who he was.
2020-08-15.snippet: He’s not out on the campaign trail now, but when he was a young man in a hurry, he told us who he was.
2020-08-15.lead_paragraph: There’s a reason that a certain kind of journalist makes a quadrennial habit of reading “What It Takes,” Richard Ben Cramer’s gonzo classic about the 1988 presidential primary. It’s catnip to prose snobs. It’s a New Journalism masterpiece, freckled with ellipses, popping with sound effects. And it shows, better than perhaps any campaign book in the last half-century, what metabolically and psychologically distinguishes those who seek the presidency from those who consider eight nonspectacular hours at their day jobs triumph enough.
2020-08-15.headline_main: Meet Young Joe Biden, the ‘Wild Stallion’

While researchers are beginning to look at the connection between the pandemic and weight gain, it’s apparent that we’re moving less during this topsy-turvy period: A preliminary study published in May and led by Iowa State University and Trinity College Dublin reported an average 32 percent reduction in physical activity once social distancing went into effect.

2020-08-15.abstract: Francis Heaney’s the summer blockbuster this year.
2020-08-15.snippet: Francis Heaney’s the summer blockbuster this year.
2020-08-15.lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — The days are getting shorter and I was beginning to worry that we wouldn’t get a Sunday puzzle with a movie theme. This is a weird year for film buffs! I know that streaming services were affecting attendance long before 2020, but there were still plenty of movie theaters that employed popcorn poppers, projectionists and ushers, and I have fond memories of going to a movie during a New York summer like this one just to freeze myself for a couple of hours and recalibrate my feelings toward torrid heat. I worry now about those places and the people who made them run. On the other hand, I know that many of us have probably knocked rafts of movies off our watch lists, and there are new summer movies that went straight to the small screen, so cinematic life goes on, even if it’s limping at the moment.
2020-08-15.headline_main: Alternative Cinema

Far-right activists and white supremacist militia groups planned to gather at Stone Mountain to symbolically “defend” the monument, and antiracist and far-left counterprotesters planned to confront them.

2020-08-15.abstract: Our game lets you follow the 19th Amendment’s journey from passage in the Senate to ratification by 36 states.
2020-08-15.snippet: Our game lets you follow the 19th Amendment’s journey from passage in the Senate to ratification by 36 states.
2020-08-15.lead_paragraph: On June 4, 1919, the Susan B. Anthony Amendment came before the Senate. It was the fifth time that the proposal — first introduced in 1878, and already approved by the House of Representatives — had been put to senators; four months earlier, it had fallen short by just one vote. But on this day, the federal lawmakers voted 56 to 25, to pass the law, amend the constitution and establish women’s right to vote in the United States.
2020-08-15.headline_main: Join the Final Drive to Suffrage

2020-08-16.abstract: Catch Misha Green’s horror series set in the Jim Crow North, and revisit a classic American road trip movie.
2020-08-16.snippet: Catch Misha Green’s horror series set in the Jim Crow North, and revisit a classic American road trip movie.
2020-08-16.lead_paragraph: LOVECRAFT COUNTRY 9 p.m. on HBO. H.P. Lovecraft’s characters and stories were a profound influence on the horror genre, but his legacy and work is also marred by racism. This series, based on Matt Ruff’s novel of the same name, reframes Lovecraft’s work by focusing on Black characters and blending supernatural horror with a critique on racial injustice. Jonathan Majors stars as Atticus Freeman, a Korean War veteran who teams up with his uncle (played by Courtney B. Vance) and his friend Letitia (Jurnee Smollett) to navigate 1950s New England in search of his missing father. In an article about the series, Salamishah Tillet wrote that its showrunner, Misha Green, also references “works by literary figures like James Baldwin and Ntozake Shange to create a provocative show that is landing amid a broader national conversation about race and representation.”
2020-08-16.headline_main: What’s on TV Sunday: ‘Lovecraft Country’ and ‘Paris, Texas’

When Amy Pascal was pushed out of Sony Pictures in 2015, she got an exit package and production deal worth a reported $40 million.

2020-08-17.abstract: Even amid all of the suffering, give yourself permission to be OK.
2020-08-17.snippet: Even amid all of the suffering, give yourself permission to be OK.
2020-08-17.lead_paragraph: When the coronavirus pandemic began to spread, I expected it to upend my life. As a Black disabled woman living in New York, once the American epicenter of the crisis, I thought I would bear the brunt of whatever was about to come.
2020-08-17.headline_main: It’s OK to Feel OK Right Now

2020-08-17.abstract: The comedian’s culinary apprenticeship continues with a new self-shot season. And a cult classic starring Rose McGowan arrives on Shudder.
2020-08-17.snippet: The comedian’s culinary apprenticeship continues with a new self-shot season. And a cult classic starring Rose McGowan arrives on Shudder.
2020-08-17.lead_paragraph: AMY SCHUMER LEARNS TO COOK 10 p.m. on Food Network. Many of us took to the culinary arts when restaurants began to shut down in the United States in March. The comedian and actress Amy Schumer went one step further, filming her forays into cooking and sharing them with the world. Schumer’s husband, Chris Fischer, a chef, is her guide in the home kitchen. During the first batch of episodes they made latkes, panzanella salad, fish tacos and other dishes that amateurs can try to tackle. They also bantered, shared relationship advice and offered a peek into their personal lives, with their baby, Gene, their nanny, Jane, and their dog, Tatiana, all making appearances. The second season begins tonight with an episode about how to make homemade versions of frozen food favorites and children’s meals that will also appeal to adults.
2020-08-17.headline_main: What’s on TV Monday: ‘Amy Schumer Learns to Cook’ and ‘Jawbreaker’

2020-08-17.abstract: How the Dallas Mavericks’ two young European stars fare on the league’s biggest stage looms as one of the foremost curiosities of the playoffs.
2020-08-17.snippet: How the Dallas Mavericks’ two young European stars fare on the league’s biggest stage looms as one of the foremost curiosities of the playoffs.
2020-08-17.lead_paragraph: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. — For the past several days in the N.B.A. bubble, Luka Doncic and Kristaps Porzingis have been asked various forms of the same question, occasionally with the tone of a lecture.
2020-08-17.headline_main: Luka Doncic and Kristaps Porzingis Set for N.B.A. Playoffs Debut

2020-08-17.abstract: Progressive candidates are winning. The pandemic increased support for “Medicare for all.” What does Mr. Sanders make of it? “He may feel a little bit like Moses.”
2020-08-17.snippet: Progressive candidates are winning. The pandemic increased support for “Medicare for all.” What does Mr. Sanders make of it? “He may feel a little bit like Moses.”
2020-08-17.lead_paragraph: Bernie Sanders, stoop-shouldered in his navy-blue suit jacket, adjusted his chair and stared into the camera as the livestream began this month. He bobbed and jabbed both fists in the air, verklempt. He smiled.
2020-08-17.headline_main: Bernie Sanders Lost Again, but This Time He’ll Deliver a Victory Speech

2020-08-17.abstract: Under pressure from governments and investors, industry leaders like BP and Shell are accelerating their production of cleaner energy.
2020-08-17.snippet: Under pressure from governments and investors, industry leaders like BP and Shell are accelerating their production of cleaner energy.
2020-08-17.lead_paragraph: This may turn out to be the year that oil giants, especially in Europe, started looking more like electric companies.
2020-08-17.headline_main: Europe’s Big Oil Companies Are Turning Electric

2020-08-17.abstract: The Chinese phone number, ending in five 8s, drew 5,000 bids because it’s considered auspicious. Such phone numbers are coveted status symbols in China.
2020-08-17.snippet: The Chinese phone number, ending in five 8s, drew 5,000 bids because it’s considered auspicious. Such phone numbers are coveted status symbols in China.
2020-08-17.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The defendant wasn’t so lucky. But one fortunate bidder is hoping the person’s phone number will be.
2020-08-17.headline_main: Defendant’s Luck Runs Out. But the Lucky Phone Number Fetches $325,000.

2020-08-17.abstract: The extremist group Al Shabab has escalated assaults in recent months, even as the country confronts a host of other challenges, including containing the coronavirus.
2020-08-17.snippet: The extremist group Al Shabab has escalated assaults in recent months, even as the country confronts a host of other challenges, including containing the coronavirus.
2020-08-17.lead_paragraph: MOGADISHU, Somalia — A terrorist attack on a popular hotel in the Somali capital that left at least 16 people dead, including five assailants, ended with the dramatic rescue of more than 200 people on Sunday after a raging gun battle.
2020-08-17.headline_main: Attack on Beachside Somalia Hotel Kills at Least 16

2020-08-17.abstract: Smith’s series of seasonal novels has kept pace with the world’s news, and now she brings it to a close with the arrival of Covid-19.
2020-08-17.snippet: Smith’s series of seasonal novels has kept pace with the world’s news, and now she brings it to a close with the arrival of Covid-19.
2020-08-17.lead_paragraph: A favorite bit of advice about writing criticism is from Anthony Lane, in the introduction to his collection “Nobody’s Perfect.” It’s just five words: “Never read the publicity material.” The problem, he writes, is that the provided synopses deliver “a false impression of coherence.” My corollary to Lane’s maxim would be: “Even dust jackets.”
2020-08-17.headline_main: Ali Smith’s ‘Summer’ Ends a Funny, Political, Very Up-to-Date Quartet

2020-08-17.abstract: Family members play an important role in the care we provide. I miss them.
2020-08-17.snippet: Family members play an important role in the care we provide. I miss them.
2020-08-17.lead_paragraph: One morning in early March, during what would be our last week of normalcy, my team gathered outside our patient’s room on morning rounds. The beleaguered overnight intern began to present the details of the case. Then stopped. We needed to wait. The patient’s wife was on the way — and we couldn’t start without her.
2020-08-17.headline_main: Families Are Central to Critical Care. But the Waiting Room Is Empty.

2020-08-17.abstract: Spending more time on screens, staying up late and sleeping late may require some adjustments for the start of the school year.
2020-08-17.snippet: Spending more time on screens, staying up late and sleeping late may require some adjustments for the start of the school year.
2020-08-17.lead_paragraph: So how are you sleeping these days? Some children — and adolescents — may actually be getting more sleep, or better sleep, while others are struggling with disrupted routines, anxiety and electronics, sometimes all at the same time. And even for those who have settled into new schedules that leave them reasonably well rested, back-to-school season may mean a possibly problematic reset.
2020-08-17.headline_main: How Children’s Sleep Habits Have Changed in the Pandemic

2020-08-17.abstract: If we force teachers to return to schools during an out-of-control pandemic, I don’t know how many will stick around.
2020-08-17.snippet: If we force teachers to return to schools during an out-of-control pandemic, I don’t know how many will stick around.
2020-08-17.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Usually on the first day back to work after summer break, there’s this buzzing, buoyant energy in the air. My school is a small school-within-a-school designated to serve gifted children, so there are only 16 teachers and staff members. We typically meet in a colleague’s tidy classroom, filled with natural light and the earthy smell of coffee.
2020-08-17.headline_main: Get Ready for a Teacher Shortage Like We’ve Never Seen Before

2020-08-17.snippet: The 20th century is full of examples of the false promise of suburban living.
2020-08-17.lead_paragraph: Walking the streets of San Francisco during these coronavirus days, you’ll see a sight rarer than Bigfoot: “for sale” and “for rent” signs.
2020-08-17.headline_main: Want to Flee the City for Suburbia? Think Again

2020-08-17.abstract: A retired nurse from Pennsylvania, she had wanted to move to Manhattan since she was a child. So when the coronavirus hit, she came anyway.
2020-08-17.snippet: A retired nurse from Pennsylvania, she had wanted to move to Manhattan since she was a child. So when the coronavirus hit, she came anyway.
2020-08-17.lead_paragraph: Cynthia Lanzino wanted to move to New York City ever since she was a child growing up in Pennsylvania. So this spring, Ms. Lanzino, 63, decided not to wait any longer. Even if there was a pandemic.
2020-08-17.headline_main: Moving to New York, Despite the Pandemic

2020-08-17.abstract: Fans have long been prized by leagues for their big spending on tickets and overpriced beer. Now, amid the pandemic, spectators deserve appreciation for making sports entertaining.
2020-08-17.snippet: Fans have long been prized by leagues for their big spending on tickets and overpriced beer. Now, amid the pandemic, spectators deserve appreciation for making sports entertaining.
2020-08-17.lead_paragraph: Sports went away and then returned to empty arenas during the past five months of the coronavirus pandemic, pushing fans ever further to the periphery of professional sports.
2020-08-17.headline_main: If a Dunk Echoes Across an Empty Gym, Is It Still Must-See TV?

2020-08-17.abstract: Some might be better off not knowing they have breast cancer because they are likely to die of other causes long before breast cancer would threaten their health.
2020-08-17.snippet: Some might be better off not knowing they have breast cancer because they are likely to die of other causes long before breast cancer would threaten their health.
2020-08-17.lead_paragraph: The shutdowns and fears provoked by the Covid-19 pandemic threw a monkey wrench into many aspects of routine medical care, especially for older people justifiably wary about being exposed to the virus in a medical setting. While many facilities have now created “safe spaces” to resume in-person exams, some of the resulting postponements of routine checkups can have a major impact on the severity of an undetected or untreated disease and sometimes even the chances of survival.
2020-08-17.headline_main: Are Mammograms Worthwhile for Older Women?

2020-08-17.snippet: The creators of “Slow Burn” have a new season of their podcast “Fiasco,” which looks at the yearslong fight over school desegregation in Boston.

2020-08-17.abstract: It might be worth thousands at auction.
2020-08-17.snippet: It might be worth thousands at auction.
2020-08-17.lead_paragraph: Ellis Whiteaker, 11, didn’t know what he might find when he went hunting in his basement in Fayetteville, N.C. But he had seen a call for fishing antiques on a social-networking app he uses (he’s been an avid fishermen since age 4) and knew that his grandfather, a former Air Force pilot who passed away before Ellis was born, had left some very old stuff in boxes.
2020-08-17.headline_main: Check Your Basement for Old Fishing Gear

2020-08-17.abstract: On Aug. 18, 1920, a young state legislator listened to his mama, and Tennessee became the final state to ratify the 19th Amendment.
2020-08-17.snippet: On Aug. 18, 1920, a young state legislator listened to his mama, and Tennessee became the final state to ratify the 19th Amendment.
2020-08-17.lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — Tuesday marks 100 years since the Tennessee General Assembly voted to ratify the 19th Amendment, which gave American women the right to vote and shifted the national political landscape as thoroughly as any earthquake, tornado, and tidal wave combined.
2020-08-17.headline_main: The Final Battleground in the Fight for Suffrage

2020-08-17.abstract: Emerging data show that some of the coronavirus’s most potent damage is inflicted on the heart.
2020-08-17.snippet: Emerging data show that some of the coronavirus’s most potent damage is inflicted on the heart.
2020-08-17.lead_paragraph: SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes Covid-19, was initially thought to primarily impact the lungs — SARS stands for “severe acute respiratory syndrome.” Now we know there is barely a part of the body this infection spares. And emerging data show that some of the virus’s most potent damage is inflicted on the heart.
2020-08-17.headline_main: Covid-19 Is Creating a Wave of Heart Disease

2020-08-17.abstract: A small study prompted fears that neck gaiters could spread more virus droplets than they stop. But new research shows that those face coverings can protect just as well as other cloth masks.
2020-08-17.snippet: A small study prompted fears that neck gaiters could spread more virus droplets than they stop. But new research shows that those face coverings can protect just as well as other cloth masks.
2020-08-17.lead_paragraph: The reports of the demise of the neck gaiter have been greatly exaggerated.
2020-08-17.headline_main: Save the Gaiters!

2020-08-17.abstract: The senator from Vermont explains why the left still has a fighting chance.
2020-08-17.snippet: The senator from Vermont explains why the left still has a fighting chance.
2020-08-17.lead_paragraph: I have said goodbye to Bernie Sanders before. There was the parting pageantry of the 2016 Democratic Convention where Mr. Sanders conceded the nomination to Hillary Clinton, closing out a primary season so tight it had given even the most pessimistic of leftists a thrill of hope. As he called for unity against Donald Trump in his farewell, the news network’s camera found a crying 22-year-old Bernie delegate in a Robin Hood hat, and the internet tore him apart. Laugh it up, I thought; there will be a next time.
2020-08-17.headline_main: I Asked Bernie Sanders if It Was All Over. ‘No,’ He Groaned.

2020-08-17.abstract: The justices will consider whether a student’s First Amendment lawsuit may proceed after a college in Georgia abandoned its restrictions.
2020-08-17.snippet: The justices will consider whether a student’s First Amendment lawsuit may proceed after a college in Georgia abandoned its restrictions.
2020-08-17.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A few years ago, a college student in Georgia stood on a stool outside a campus food court to talk about his Christian faith. He spoke for 20 minutes about human frailty and the possibility of salvation when school officials told him he had to stop or face discipline.
2020-08-17.headline_main: A College’s ‘Free Speech Areas’ Face Supreme Court Review

2020-08-17.abstract: Those with budgets that rely heavily on tourism, sales taxes or direct state assistance will face particular distress.
2020-08-17.snippet: Those with budgets that rely heavily on tourism, sales taxes or direct state assistance will face particular distress.
2020-08-17.lead_paragraph: The coronavirus recession will erode city budgets in many insidious ways. It will slash the casino revenues that Detroit relies on. It will squeeze the state aid that is a lifeblood to Rochester and Buffalo in upstate New York. It will cut the sales tax revenue in New Orleans and Baton Rouge, where a healthy government depends on people buying things.
2020-08-17.headline_main: The Recession Is About to Slam Cities. Not Just the Blue-State Ones.

2020-08-17.abstract: Is Biden-Harris the answer to the confusion and sorrow of Trump’s America?
2020-08-17.snippet: Is Biden-Harris the answer to the confusion and sorrow of Trump’s America?
2020-08-17.lead_paragraph: Bret Stephens: Gail, last week I argued that what the Republicans need this November is “the political equivalent of an unsedated colonoscopy.” Several readers, including a couple of medical professionals, wrote in to say that unsedated colonoscopies actually aren’t all that bad. (I’ll take their word for it.)
2020-08-17.headline_main: Welcome, Democrats, to Wherever It Is That We Are

2020-08-17.abstract: In what may be the world’s most important math puzzle, researchers are trying to figure out how many people in a community must be immune before the coronavirus fades.
2020-08-17.snippet: In what may be the world’s most important math puzzle, researchers are trying to figure out how many people in a community must be immune before the coronavirus fades.
2020-08-17.lead_paragraph: We’ve known from the beginning how the end will arrive. Eventually, the coronavirus will be unable to find enough susceptible hosts to survive, fading out wherever it briefly emerges.
2020-08-17.headline_main: What if ‘Herd Immunity’ Is Closer Than Scientists Thought?

2020-08-17.abstract: As millions of American families face an uncertain start to the school year, the anger of women who find themselves expected to be teacher, caregiver, employee and parent is fueling a political uprising.
2020-08-17.snippet: As millions of American families face an uncertain start to the school year, the anger of women who find themselves expected to be teacher, caregiver, employee and parent is fueling a political uprising.

2020-08-17.snippet: The pandemic has created a bicycle boom — and a shortage. Giant, the Taiwanese juggernaut, is trying to meet demand while navigating the politics of trade.
2020-08-17.lead_paragraph: TAICHUNG, Taiwan — Because gyms are closed and we could all use a little more exercise; because we are avoiding buses and trains; because we are in need of outdoor group activities; or perhaps just because the pandemic has made us crave simple pleasures like the wind against our faces, bicycle sales are soaring around the world.
2020-08-17.headline_main: Sorry, the World’s Biggest Bike Maker Can’t Help You Buy a Bike Right Now

2020-08-17.abstract: President Trump is struggling to attract and retain a reliable stable of millionaires and billionaires willing to write seven-figure checks, despite his takeover of the Republican Party and a policy agenda that largely serves the interests of America’s ultrawealthy. 2020-08-17.abstract: New children’s books published to mark the 19th Amendment’s 100th anniversary provide a wider lens than Alice Paul and dig deeper than “Girls Rule!”
2020-08-17.snippet: New children’s books published to mark the 19th Amendment’s 100th anniversary provide a wider lens than Alice Paul and dig deeper than “Girls Rule!”
2020-08-17.lead_paragraph: If you’re a parent of kids (who am I kidding: girls) and possess a passing interest in basic human rights and dignity, you most likely have been gifted some of the books I have come to call the You Go Girl Collection. Infant libraries once home mostly to overinvested bunny mothers and magic pasta pots are now studded with bobble-headed cartoon depictions of female pioneers from Ada Lovelace to Bessie Coleman, while older kids now read about women resisting, persisting and dissenting till they puke.

2020-08-17.lead_paragraph: If the last few months have taught us anything, it’s that the time for representation is yesterday — and that people are willing to make public calls for change. But undoing years of messaging about the irrelevance of Black lives and voices isn’t easy. The TV and film industry, in particular, has been slow to include Black characters that don’t fall into racist stereotypes. (Yes, Disney archives, I’m looking at you.)
